video.title: Stacks (Data Structure) - Beau teaches JavaScript
video.description:
Stacks are a programming data structure. Learn how they work in JavaScript.

Code: 
🔗 http://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/yMBGbR?editors=0012
More information:
🔗 http://radar.oreilly.com/2014/03/stacks-in-javascript.html

🐦Beau Carnes on Twitter: https://twitter.com/carnesbeau

🔗 Check out Beau's algorithms course from Manning Publications: https://www.manning.com/livevideo/algorithms-in-motion?a_aid=algmotion&a_bid=9022d293

⭐JavaScript Playlists⭐
▶Design Patterns: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbnZtkAI3BqcYxKnfWn_C704
▶JavaScript Basics: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbk2qRZtWSzCIN38JC_NdhW5
▶ES6: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbljtmmeS0c-CEl2LdE-eR_F
▶Data Structures and Algorithms: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkso-IbgiiP48n-O-JQA9PJ
▶Clean Code: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkK24EaPurzMq0-kw5U9pJh

-
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

topLevelComment.author: kashinath arora
topLevelComment.text:
One Question; what if we peek on empty stack here ? Shouldn't we check in peek function whether count is 0 or not ?
Is it something like it should return -1 in case of empty stack ? But here storage object don't have -1 as a key... suggestions would be appreciated.

topLevelComment.author: Abdallah Rawashdeh
topLevelComment.text: Why he used storage as object [not array] in the Stack implementation ?

replies.author: Utkarsh Singh
replies.text: Because you can just pop and push on an array in JS so there would be no learning of how to actually implement it

topLevelComment.author: Hasan Said
topLevelComment.text: Kinda of a stupid question but how was he able to make a new Stack() obj from a function?

replies.author: Marouane Souda
replies.text: Stack() is a constructor function. It "constructs" objects or "instances" by using the keyword "new" before calling it, and then storing the newly created object inside of a variable. The "new" keyword takes care of all of that behind the scenes.

topLevelComment.author: Byazit Bostami
topLevelComment.text: Why did you use this.count=0 instead of var count=0 ?

replies.author: Houman
replies.text:
The reason is that var defines a global variables, and so if you have two different stack functions, each will try to change the same global variable!

Generally speaking though, it is strongly preferred to use 'let' and 'const' to define variables, instead of var. You really shouldn't need to use 'var' ever

topLevelComment.author: blehbleh
topLevelComment.text:
Great video!  One question, 

Even though pop() removes the top element from the stack, the storage array still preservers the same size (for example, say we've pushed onto storage [10,20,40], then popped the stack, we get [10,20,], yet when doing console.log(stack.storage.length), we still get 3, not 2.

replies.author: wanderlust_rj51
replies.text:
I know it's too late to reply but for the people who are watching this video now and getting the same error, 
replace line "delete this.storage[this.count]" 
with "this.storage.splice[this.storage.length-1, 1)" or "this.storage.splice[this.count, 1)"

topLevelComment.author: Siderite Zackwehdex
topLevelComment.text: Beau, I love your videos, but please be more careful. There are a bunch of mistakes in almost every video you make. You can easily edit them or even redo them. A stack is not a First In First Out, that's a queue. I don't mind small mistakes, but if they are perennial they become annoying.

replies.author: Carnaru Valentin

replies.author: OneManShow
replies.text: @Carnaru Valentin Are you serious right now? Anyone who upvoted your comment should NOT be a programmer. We don't need any more "Programmers" who hack things together and hope it works. We need programmers who are thorough, and thoughtful, and make sure their code is tested correctly before deployment. If you think that it isn't worth the teacher's time to correct mistakes in their "free" course, then you're probably the type to make programming errors and not care less about the consequences. By the way: the course isn't free, we all spend hours of our lives watching these tutorial videos. Maybe you value your time as worthless. I do not.
